posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
We’re having a debate about how to design a wrist that is both strong enough and light enough. Our general design is pivot between two masts, telescoping extender off the pivot, with gripper on a wrist at the end of the extender.

Since this group of students (& I) have not really designed a motor-powered pivot or wrist before (only pneumatics), my approach this year has been to research past robots, design/CAD some concepts, and then share with others so they can do further design iterations. Out of that the debate has sprung…

My v1 wrist seemed too heavy, using a Neo and Maxplanetary + chain/sprocket drive, and a different mentor proposed a much lighter weight design using the AM snowblower motor direct driving a hex shaft through the tube to which the gripper is connected. Reading about that motor, I’m concerned it will break, and I’m looking for a middle ground solution that is lighter than my v1 but still strong enough. I’m down to a few possibilities, and I would appreciate help from others with more experience. I estimate the torque from the gripper weight will be between 5 to 10 ft-lbs (not counting impacts and encounters with immovable objects). I’d really like to move us off the idea of using the snowblower motor.

Current middle ground ideas to drive wrist:

Neo550 (current limited to 20A) + Ultraplanetary (25:1) + sync belt + 3D printed pulleys (maybe another 2:1 reduction) with one pulley bolted to the gripper tube being rotated. Again need structure / 2 outer bearings. -->Question on this one: UP 25:1 is near the UP’s load limit with a Neo550… If I add a 2:1 reduction using pulleys, am I putting that outer 5:1 UP stage at risk (or will Onyx pulleys not be strong enough)?

Neo550 + Sport 57 100:1… This one may be it.

Or maybe I can drive a hex shaft and have the hex shaft rotate the tube using one of options above rather than bolting pulley to tube?

Thanks

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
You got any window motors or PLG motors?

From R501’s table, the list of allowed P/Ns: Current/former KOP automotive motors Denso AE235100-0160 Denso 5-163800-RC1 Denso 262100-3030 Denso 262100-3040 Bosch 6 004 RA3 194-06 Johnson Electric JE-PLG-149 Johnson Electric JE-PLG-410

posts.name: Ido Keren
posts.cooked: Our current design (not tested) includes a 775 powered winch with a thin rope clamped on the static side of the arm. The gripper is free to rotate on the end of the arm and has a spring to pull it down and the string from the winch to balance it. We plane to use through bore encoder on the wrist and do our PID on that.

posts.name: david
posts.cooked:
Here are some ideas that might help:

Use pneumatics for a simple pivot if you don’t need the extra capabilities of a fully actuating wrist, makes life easier for everyone.

Use pneumatics for a simple pivot if you don’t need the extra capabilities of a fully actuating wrist, makes life easier for everyone.

The REV gears have a max spline pattern + hole pattern. It should be really easy to make a dead axel with 7/8 bushings + tube and bolt your wrist directly to the gear, you can then run a maxplanetary/ultra planetary directly geared against it, and that should be reasonably compact and simple, there should be room for an absolute encoder if you are smart about it.

The REV gears have a max spline pattern + hole pattern. It should be really easy to make a dead axel with 7/8 bushings + tube and bolt your wrist directly to the gear, you can then run a maxplanetary/ultra planetary directly geared against it, and that should be reasonably compact and simple, there should be room for an absolute encoder if you are smart about it.

I threw together some rough cad for reference to help visualize things, I also just wanted to learn how to cad a wrist lol. Feel free to copy or do whatever with it. The design practices might not be the best as I haven’t spent too much time on it, but this might be a feasible way of doing a wrist.

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 3 million users.

I don’t recommend doing the neo cutout thing, but I don’t know your team’s resources or what the design looks like, but hopefully, this is helpful.

Weights under 5 lbs right now, you could probably shave off half a pound by replacing the gears with a belt system and another 1.5 lbs by replacing the maxplanetary system with something lighter.

You could also get rid of the tube machining by using a maxtube instead of a 2x2, and with some creative packaging, you could replace the 1/8 plates with maxtube as well. image 789×622 65.8 KB

image 789×622 65.8 KB

image 789×622 65.8 KB

I’ll add an absolute encoder setup quickly, but hopefully, this is helpful.

Edit: Absolute encoder added image 647×584 59.7 KB

posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked: Wow, this is the exact same design idea my team is planning on doing! This ways it’ll absorb impacts against walls better.

posts.name: Joseph Barry
posts.cooked: Great packaging! You may be able to use a much lighter and smaller Neo 550 and ultraplanetary combo for this application if your end effector isn’t too heavy. This assumes this is for a “wrist” and not an “elbow”…

posts.name: Ryan Swanson
posts.cooked:
Here’s what we’re doing. 125:1 Maxplanetary into a MAX 90 Degree gearbox driving a 20 tooth gear which turns a 60 tooth gear. Overall reduction of 375:1 leaves it easily controllable and doesn’t allow it to backdrive.

Gearboxes package nicely between two arms with some polycarbonate spacer plates to make room for the NEO. I’d stick to a NEO for a wrist application personally… having an underpowered wrist wouldn’t be a fun time. Screenshot_20230125_101956_Gallery 1920×864 138 KB

Screenshot_20230125_101956_Gallery 1920×864 138 KB

Screenshot_20230125_101956_Gallery 1920×864 138 KB

posts.name: Ido Keren
posts.cooked: Cool! We didn’t even consider this benefit…

posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked:
Well, I’m very pragmatic when it comes to the destructibility of our robot… or rather the destructive tendency of drivers.

all kidding aside I got the idea from the Everybot. It showed how it smacked the wall and it wasn’t rigid enough to break anything. So I wanted to incorporate that into our design. I think it will also be simpler to make, which is a major selling point.

posts.name: Magor Pocsveiler
posts.cooked: Have you thought about a four bar linkage? It might make your situation simpler.

posts.name: Max DeVos
posts.cooked:
Is your concern with weight an issue of total robot weight, or a concern with an increased moment of inertia (lever force) of the arm?

If your concern is the moment of inertia, you’ve got a few other options. You could mount the wrist motor/gearbox further up on the arm and use a timing belt or chain to transfer the power to the wrist. I can CAD an example of this if it would be of benefit to you.

If you’re feeling particularly brave, you can do something adjacent to what 971 did in 2018 , with the gearbox for the wrist mounted in the drivetrain with a timing belt ran through the entire length of the arm and then continuously updated via software to remain in sync with the arm. I’ve attached a picture of this which I pulled from their technical binder . 971 graciously supplies their CAD files as well, so those are available for inspiration.

971 2018 ArmWrist 612×635 119 KB .

971 2018 ArmWrist 612×635 119 KB

971 2018 ArmWrist 612×635 119 KB

971 used steel cable to drive their upper arm. An interesting aspect of this implementation is that every joint is effectively a virtual fourbar due to the cable. To use steel cable there must either be a very high amount of tension or be limited to ~180deg of motion. I would not recommend using a timing belt; the loads on the arm would make it liable to teeth skipping.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: I really hope 971 just dusts off those 2019 CAD files and enters a clone for 2023 (or someone does at least - that was a pretty robot, and it’s arguably better suited for 2023 than it was for 2019)

posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
Closing the loop; I guess we’re going to try the lightweight snowblower motor wrist design. At least the snowblower motors are cheap (like $19 a pop on AM).

I finished my Neo-MaxP-chain design, which will be waiting in the wings if the snowblower motor route ends up failing too much.

As a team that’s done the final stage of a joint(s) on an arm with gears before, I don’t recommend it, I would really use some # 25 chain here to help absorb any shock.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
I worry about that little 2x2 to 1x1 joint on the arm side of your wrist design.  Will these be welded?

If not, you might consider inverting the design so that the two 1x1 outside beams come from the intake, and the 2x2 middle beam comes from the arm
